engagementHook.title: The Body's Wi-Fi
engagementHook.content: Your body contains approximately 37 trillion cells that must work together seamlessly. How do they communicate? Unlike humans using phones, cells use chemical signals—hormones, neurotransmitters, and signalling molecules—that travel through your bloodstream and bind to specific receptors. Today we explore this invisible cellular internet.

keyConcepts.definition: The process of converting a chemical signal from outside the cell into a specific cellular response through a series of molecular steps.
Proteins embedded in the cell membrane or located inside the cell that bind to specific signalling molecules (ligands) to initiate a cellular response.
A molecule that binds to a specific receptor protein, acting as a chemical signal to trigger a cellular response.
Small, non-protein molecules that relay signals from receptors on the cell surface to target molecules inside the cell, amplifying the signal.
The final stage of signal transduction where the cell carries out a specific action, such as activating enzymes, changing gene expression, or altering membrane permeability.

contentSections.title: Overview of Cell Signalling
contentSections.content:
Cell signalling is essential for coordinating activities in multicellular organisms. The process follows three key stages:

  • Reception: A signalling molecule (ligand) binds to a receptor protein on or in the target cell.
  • Transduction: The binding event triggers a series of molecular relay steps, often involving second messengers like cAMP.
  • Response: The signal reaches its target, activating specific cellular processes such as enzyme activation, protein synthesis, or changes in cell shape.

Receptor proteins are highly specific—each receptor binds only to particular ligands, ensuring precise communication between cells.

contentSections.title: Types of Cell Surface Receptors
contentSections.content: Cell surface receptors are categorised into three main types based on their structure and function: G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs), and ion channel receptors.
keyPoints: GPCRs are the largest family of cell surface receptors
RTKs often trigger cell growth and division pathways
Ion channel receptors open gates for ions when activated
contentSections.example: Insulin binds to RTKs, triggering glucose uptake.

contentSections.title: When Signalling Goes Wrong
contentSections.content:
Disruptions in cell signalling pathways can lead to serious diseases. Cancer often results from mutations in signalling proteins that cause cells to divide uncontrollably.

Example: The Ras protein is a key component of growth factor signalling. Mutations in the Ras gene keep it permanently activated, leading to continuous cell division signals even without growth factors present. This is found in approximately 30% of human cancers.

multipleChoice.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three main stages of signal transduction?

They block all cell surface receptors
